current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To designate the Junction City Community-Based Outpatient
		  Clinic located at 715 Southwind Drive, Junction City, Kansas, as the Lieutenant
		  General Richard J. Seitz Community-Based Outpatient Clinic.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was read twice and referred to the

header.#text:
Lieutenant General Richard J.
			 Seitz Community-Based Outpatient Clinic

text.#text:
Lieutenant
			 General Richard J. Seitz served as the cadet commander of a unit of the Reserve
			 Officers’ Training Corps at Leavenworth High School in Leavenworth, Kansas,
			 where he earned the American Legion Cup as an outstanding cadet;

at age 25,
			 Lieutenant General Seitz as a major, was given command of the 2nd Battalion of
			 the 517th Parachute Infantry Regimental Combat Team, becoming the youngest
			 battalion commander in the Army;

along with the
			 7th Armored Division, the battalion commanded by Lieutenant General Seitz
			 formed what became known as Task Force Seitz at the Battle of the Bulge with
			 the mission to plug the gaps on the north slope of the Bulge when the Germans
			 attempted to break out;

the service of
			 Lieutenant General Seitz earned him the Silver Star, 2 Bronze Stars, the Purple
			 Heart, and many other acknowledgments during his 37-year career in the
			 Army;

after victory in
			 Europe, Lieutenant General Seitz remained in the Army, commanding the 2nd
			 Airborne Battle Group, 503rd Infantry Regiment, and the 82nd Airborne
			 Division;

on retiring in
			 1978, Lieutenant General Seitz settled in Junction City, Kansas, near Ft.
			 Riley, where he would greet deploying and returning units from Iraq and
			 Afghanistan at all times of the day;

Lieutenant
			 General Seitz remained active in the wider community, working with the Coronado
			 Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America, the Fort Riley National Bank, Rotary
			 International, and the Association of the United States Army and serving on the
			 board of the Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum;

Lieutenant
			 General Seitz had a passion for mentoring young officers and noncommissioned
			 officers at Fort Riley, never ceasing to be a soldier, according to his son,
			 Richard M. Seitz;

Lieutenant
			 General Seitz was named an Outstanding Citizen of Kansas;

in 2012 an
			 elementary school at Fort Riley was named in honor of Lieutenant General Seitz,
			 which is meaningful because he believed the fate of the United States relied on
			 young children and the teachers who inspire them;

quote.#tail:
and his
			 message was always to

quote.#text:
respect the teachers and be a
			 learner

text.#text:
during visits to
			 the elementary school, Lieutenant General Seitz would talk with the students
			 about what it meant to be a

the family and
			 friends of Lieutenant General Seitz have described him as a gentleman,
			 compassionate, respected, full of integrity, gracious, giving, and a remarkable
			 individual; and

Lieutenant
			 General Seitz lived each day to its fullest and his commitment to his fellow
			 man serves as an inspiration to all the people of the United States.
